text: Akt Controls <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Production in Other Cell Types

After establishing the role of <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase - dependent signaling to Akt in L929 cells , we sought to expand our study to other cell types that are known to undergo necroptotic cell death .

<extra_id_0> Fas-associated protein with death domain <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> FADD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) - deficient Jurkat T lymphocytes and the macrophage cell lines ( J774A.1 and RAW264.7 ) are other models of necroptosis , which can be induced by stimulation with <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or zVAD.fmk , respectively [ 17 ] .

Similar to L929 cells , a <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase dependent increase in the phosphorylation of Thr308 on Akt occurred during necroptosis ( Fig . 8B , D , F ) in these cell types .

Furthermore , <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels were increased in each of these cell types during necroptosis and efficiently inhibited by both <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and Akt inhibitors ( Fig . 8A , C , E ) .
However , inhibition of Akt did not protect these cells from death ( Fig .

These results indicate that regulation of autocrine <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis and necroptosis - associated inflammatory signaling may be a more important function of Akt pathway activation by <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase in multiple cell types compared to its contribution to cell death .
We next chose to look at the role of Akt in necroptosis in mouse lung fibroblasts .

Lung fibroblasts selected to survive after deletion of all three Akt isoforms [ 40 ] were resistant to cell death induced by the addition of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and zVAD.fmk .

Expression of catalytically active Akt ( Myr-Akt ) in these cells restored <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA production in response to <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and zVAD.fmk ( Fig . 8G ) without re-establishing cell death ( Fig .

Consistent with our earlier Akt knockdown data , lung fibroblasts expressing endogenous <extra_id_0> Akt1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> Akt2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were phosphorylated on Thr308 in response to <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and zVAD.fmk ( Fig .

S9E ) and in both cases robust <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA upregulation occurred under necroptotic conditions ( Fig . 8H ) .

These data further support the notion that Akt activity is critical for autocrine <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis , even in the absence of necroptotic cell death , indicating an unexpected differentiation between Akt - mediated inflammatory signaling under necroptotic conditions and cell death per se .
